Description: OVERSIGHT OF CLEANUP FOR US DOE WASTE SITES IN WYOMING`

THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO DEVELOP AND BUILD CARBON MANAGEMENT INFRASTRUCTURE IN REGIONS ACROSS THE 
UNITED STATES IN ORDER TO MEET OUR NET-ZERO GOALS. HOWEVER, THESE PROJECTS EITHER WILL NOT HAPPEN, OR 
WILL NOT HAPPEN AT THE REQUIRED SPEED, IF COMMUNITIES WHERE THE PROJECTS COULD BE MOST EFFECTIVELY 
SITED DO NOT UNDERSTAND WHAT CARBON MANAGEMENT IS, AND HOW IT FITS INTO THE LARGER ENERGY TRANSITION 
AND SOCIETY’S CLIMATE MITIGATION OBJECTIVES. THEREFORE, THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE AS FOLLOWS:

1)	TO DEVELOP TOOLS AND RESOURCES THAT CAN A) EXPLAIN THE ENERGY TRANSITION; B) EXPLAIN WHAT IS 
MEANT BY CARBON MANAGEMENT; C) EXPLAIN THE IMPACTS ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND ON HUMAN HEALTH THAT VARIOUS 
CARBON MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES AND PRACTICES MAY HAVE; AND
D) EXPLAIN THE REGULATORY FRAMEWORK THAT EXISTS TO ENSURE CARBON MANAGEMENT PROJECTS ARE PROPERLY 
DESIGNED AND DEPLOYED.

2)	TO PLAN, ORGANIZE, AND PRODUCE ONE LARGE (300-500 PERSON) CARBON MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY SUMMIT IN 
HOUSTON, TX, AND 5-7 SMALLER WORKSHOPS AROUND THE COUNTRY. THE PURPOSE OF THESE EVENTS IS TO START TWO-
WAY DIALOGUE ABOUT WHAT CARBON MANAGEMENT DEPLOYMENT COULD LOOK LIKE IN THE REGIONS WHERE THE EVENTS 
ARE HELD, AND TO PRODUCTIVELY SOCIALIZE THE ASSOCIATED OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES AMONG KEY COMMUNITY 
STAKEHOLDERS.
COMPREHENSIVE TOP-DOWN AND BOTTOM-UP ESTIMATION OF ANNUAL BASIN-WIDE METHANE EMISSIONS FROM THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY, CALIFORNIA AND DENVER, COLORADO OIL AND GAS BASINS USING A MULTI-TIERED MEASUREMENT

HIGHLY REPLICABLE, AND INTEGRATED SYSTEM FOR MITIGATING METHANE EMISSIONS FROM NATURAL GAS-FIRED LEAN-BURN ENGINES (NG-FLBES) 
KANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY (KSU), UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA (OU), AND COOPER MACHINERY SERVICES (FORMERLY GE'S RC BUSINESS) HAVE JOINED TOGETHER TO COLLABORATE ON THE DEVELOPMENT AND MANUFACTURE OF A LOW-COST INTEGRATED SYSTEM FOR ELIMINATING METHANE EMISSIONS FROM NATURAL GAS ENGINES. THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY IS DESIGNED TO MITIGATE METHANE EMISSIONS FROM ALL INDUSTRIAL ENGINES AND REDUCE THEIR OPERATIONAL COSTS AND FUEL CONSUMPTION AND ENHANCE THEIR STABILITY AND EFFICIENCY. THE SYSTEM CAN BE INCORPORATED IN A TIMELY MANNER WITH VARIOUS NEW AND OLD INDUSTRIAL ENGINES WITHOUT ANY SPECIFIC LIMITATIONS. IT CAN ELIMINATE THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH ONSITE UTILITIES (E.G., ELECTRICITY, WATER) TYPICALLY REQUIRED IN OTHER TECHNICAL APPROACHES. THE TUBULAR STRUCTURE OF THE MEMBRANE REACTOR ENABLES A COMPETITIVE MANUFACTURING PRICE AND EASY INTEGRATION. ADDITIONALLY, THE MEMBRANE REACTOR IN A NOVEL TUBULAR GEOMETRY IS MORE ROBUST IN ITS ABILITY TO HANDLE THERMAL, CHEMICAL, AND MECHANICAL STRESSES. THE SUCCESSFUL DEVELOPMENT OF THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY WILL BE A BREAKTHROUGH STEP TOWARD THE WIDESPREAD REDUCTION OF METHANE FROM NATURAL GAS ENGINES, AND THE TEAM PLANS TO COLLABORATE WITH OUR INDUSTRIAL PARTNERS TO FULLY COMMERCIALIZE THE TECHNOLOGY DUE TO ITS MARKET IMPACT AND NEEDS.

STORAGE TANK EMISSIONS ASSESSMENTS IN THE MARCELLUS (STEAM) TO ACQUIRE NEW KNOWLEDGE WITH SCIENCE (TANKS)

THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE IS TO ACQUIRE NEW, SCIENCE-BASED KNOWLEDGE TO IMPROVE THE OVERALL UNDERSTANDING OF METHANE AND OTHER EMISSIONS FROM STORAGE TANKS AT UPSTREAM AND MIDSTREAM OIL AND NATURAL GAS SITES IN PORTIONS OF THE APPALACHIAN BASIN, WHICH ARE KNOWN TO CONTRIBUTE TO METHANE AND VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUND (VOC) EMISSIONS THAT IMPACT LOCAL AND GLOBAL AIR QUALITY.

DETAILED MEASUREMENT INFORMED METHANE EMISSION INVENTORY OF THE HAYNESVILLE SHALE BASIN. GTI ENERGY ALONG WITH CHESAPEAKE ENERGY AND PACIFIC NORTHWEST NATIONAL LABORATORY (PNNL) WILL IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE A METHODOLOGY FOR RECONCILING BOTTOM-UP (CALCULATED) ESTIMATES OF METHANE EMISSIONS WITH TOP DOWN/MEASURED ESTIMATES OF METHANE EMISSIONS IN THE HAYNESVILLE SHALE BASIN (HAYNESVILLE). THE EFFORT INCLUDES SCALING THE ESTIMATE UP TO CREATE AN INVENTORY OF TOTAL EMISSIONS IN THE HAYNESVILLE. THE PROJECT WILL ACT AS A NOVEL, LARGE-SCALE, AND INDEPENDENT FIELD VALIDATION OF THE EXTENSIVE, MULTI-MILLION-DOLLAR GTI VERITAS INITIATIVE (VERITAS) MEASUREMENT AND RECONCILIATION PROTOCOLS.

BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW (BIL) - ACID MINE DRAINAGE AND RARE EARTH ELEMENTS (AMDREE): INTEGRATED TREATMENT OF ACID MINE DRAINAGE AND RARE EARTH PRODUCTION

THE PROJECT WILL COMPLETE A FRONT-END ENGINEERING DESIGN (FEED) STUDY ACCORDING TO THE AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF COST ENGINEERS (AACE) CLASS 3 GUIDELINES FOR THE PROPOSED RARE EARTH ELEMENTS (REE) DEMONSTRATION FACILITY.

BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW (BIL) - RECOVERY AND REFINING OF RARE EARTH ELEMENTS FROM LIGNITE MINE WASTES
THE PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A CLASS 3 COST ESTIMATE AND ASSOCIATED FRONT-END ENGINEERING DESIGN (FEED) STUDY ACCORDING TO THE AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF COST ENGINEERS (AACE) CLASS 3 GUIDELINES FOR THE PROPOSED RARE EARTH ELEMENTS (REE) DEMONSTRATION FACILITY.

A MULTI-SCALE CH4 MONITORING SYSTEM FOR ENHANCING EMISSION DETECTION, QUANTIFICATION & PREDICTION

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE PLAN TO DESIGN, DEVELOP, AND DEPLOY A CONTINUOUS METHANE (CH4) MONITORING AND REPORTING SYSTEM THAT CAN ACCELERATE A ''LEAK TIGHT'' NATURAL GAS DELIVERY SYSTEM.

POLAR BEARSM – INNOVATIVE CAPTURE OF STORAGE TANK VAPORS.

THE PROJECT WILL DEVELOP, BUILD AND TEST A NOVEL TECHNOLOGICAL APPROACH (POLAR BEARSM) TO REDUCE OR ELIMINATE METHANE EMISSIONS FROM STORAGE TANKS THROUGH PRESSURE CONTROL OF THE STORAGE TANK HEADSPACE.

SABER - SITE-AIR-BASIN EMISSIONS RECONCILIATION. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEMONSTRATE THAT (A) HIGH FREQUENCY SAMPLING CAN BE USED TO CREATE INVENTORY EMISSIONS ESTIMATES THAT ACCURATELY REPRESENT EMISSIONS IN A BASIN; AND (B) THE PROPOSED METHOD CAN BE REPLICATED IN OTHER BASINS. THE PROJECT WILL PERFORM METHOD DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION IN THE DENVER-JULESBERG BASIN (DJ), IN NORTHEASTERN COLORADO. PLANNED ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING FOR ALL BUDGET PERIODS, FINALIZING PROJECT GOVERNANCE AGREEMENTS, PLANNING THE DJ FIELD CAMPAIGN, PLANNING THE UPPER GREEN RIVER BASIN (UGR) FIELD CAMPAIGN, AND FINALIZING AND SYNTHESIZING PROJECT DATA. EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE THE PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN, COMPLETED FIELD CAMPAIGN REPORTS, PROJECT FINAL REPORT, AND UPDATED DEIA PLAN. THE STUDY WILL RESULT IN PAPERS AND REPORTS DESCRIBING THE METHODOLOGY REQUIRED FOR TOP DOWN/BOTTOM UP RECONCILIATION, PROBLEMS UNCOVERED, AND PROPOSED PROTOCOL FOR WIDESPREAD USE.
ENERGY TITLED STORAGE TANK EMISSIONS ASSESSMENT AND QUANTIFICATION.

THE OXIPERATOR FOR METHANE SLIP FROM LEAN BURN GAS ENGINES
THE OXIPERATOR IS A PATENTED, PROVEN, POROUS HEAT EXCHANGER THAT WILL COST-EFFECTIVELY OXIDIZE ALL METHANE SLIP FROM LEAN-BURN GAS ENGINES.  THIS PROJECT PROVIDES TWO PATHWAYS FOR THE OXIPERATOR TO OXIDIZE METHANE SLIP FROM LEAN BURN GAS ENGINES: A TAIL OXIPERATOR THAT CAN BE EASILY AND RAPIDLY DEPLOYED ON THE ENGINE EXHAUST; AND A TWEENER OXIPERATOR THAT WILL NOT JUST OXIDIZE METHANE BUT ALSO INCREASE ENGINE EFFICIENCY AND OUTPUT.

INTEGRATED METHANE MONITORING PLATFORM EXTENSION (IMMPE)
THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXPAND KNOWLEDGE OF METHANE MEASUREMENT TECHNOLOGIES TO IMPROVE ACCURACY, QUANTIFICATION, AND DETECTION CAPABILITIES FOR BOTH LOCAL DISTRIBUTION COMPANIES AND UPSTREAM/MIDSTREAM SEGMENTS OF THE NATURAL GAS VALUE CHAIN. UPON COMPLETION, THE IMMPE WILL OFFER A STANDARDIZED FRAMEWORK FOR METHANE MEASUREMENT AND QUANTIFICATION THAT CAN EXTEND TO UPSTREAM COMPONENTS, INCLUDING MIDSTREAM TRANSMISSION AND STORAGE, AND UPSTREAM PRODUCTION AND GATHERING RELATED ACTIVITIES. OUTCOMES THE PROJECT SEEKS TO ACHIEVE ARE: (1) FURTHER RESEARCH AND TESTING OF METHANE MONITORING TECHNOLOGY ACROSS VARIOUS ASSET CLASSES; (2) MITIGATION OF FUGITIVE EMISSIONS IDENTIFIED VIA DEPLOYED METHANE DETECTION AND MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES AND MEASUREMENT OF IMPACT (E.G., COMMUNITY IMPACT, EMISSION IMPACT); (3) DEVELOPMENT OF A TEMPLATE AND SUMMARY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR METHANE EMISSIONS MONITORING AND REDUCTIONS THAT CAN BE READILY REPLICATED BY OTHERS, INCLUDING MIDSTREAM AND UPSTREAM APPLICATIONS; AND (4) EDUCATION OF REGULATORS ON THE VALUE OF METHANE MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AS A PRUDENT ELEMENT FOR COST RECOVERY.

DEVELOPMENT OF COAL-BASED SUPERCAPACITOR MATERIALS FOR ENERGY STORAGE

THIS PROJECT WILL RESEARCH WAYS TO CREATE BATTERY PARTS (SUPERCAPACITOR MATERIALS) FROM DOMESTIC COAL IN COST EFFECTIVE MANNER.  THE RECIPIENT WILL THEN TEST THE BATTERIES MADE WITH THEIR COAL BASED MATERIALS AGAINST CURRENT BATTERIES TO DETERMINE THEIR PERFORMANCE AND THEN PERFORM A TECHNOECONOMIC EVALUATION TO DETERMINE IF THEY ARE ECONOMICALLY FEASIBLE.

ULTRA-CONDUCTIVE CARBON METAL COMPOSITE WIRE FOR ELECTRIC MOTORS
THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP COST-EFFECTIVE CARBON-METAL COMPOSITE MATERIALS WITH ENHANCED BULK ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES FOR USE IN ELECTRIC MOTORS TO INCREASE AMERICAN ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND REDUCE GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS.

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY AND COST-EFFECTIVE 
PROCEDURES TO SYNTHESIZE HIGH-VALUE CARBON QUANTUM DOTS AND GRAPHENE FOR SUPERCAPACITOR MATERIALS FROM 
COAL AND WASTE COAL.

SPRAY DEPOSITION OF COAL-DERIVED GRAPHENE-COPPER NANOCOMPOSITES FOR ADVANCED CONDUCTORS.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP LOW-COST COAL DERIVED GRAPHENE METAL NANOCOMPOSITES AS ADVANCED CONDUCTORS VIA A VERSATILE SPRAY DEPOSITION PROCESS.

NEW AWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA.  AWARD NUMBER: DE-FE0032263.  PROJECT TITLED: BIOMOLECULAR REGULATED CARBONATION PATHWAY TO PROCESS CALCIUM-RICH ALKALINE INDUSTRIAL WASTES INTO SUPPLEMENTARY CEMENTITIOUS MATERIALS (BIOCARB). 

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO TEST A LAB-SCALE BIO-REGULATED CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2) MINERALIZATION (BIOCARB) SYSTEM THAT CONVERTS CALCIUM-RICH, ALKALINE INDUSTRIAL WASTES (I.E., RECYCLED CEMENT FINES (RCF), CEMENT KILN DUST (CKD), AND HIGH CALCIUM FLY ASH) INTO CARBON-NEGATIVE SUPPLEMENTARY CEMENTITIOUS MATERIALS (SCMS) AND PERMANENTLY STORES CO2 IN THE PRODUCED SCMS. THE POTENTIAL APPLICATION OF THE PRODUCED SCMS WILL ALSO BE EVALUATED. THE CARBON NEGATIVE SCM CAN BE USED TO REPLACE OVER 30% OF PORTLAND CEMENT IN CONCRETE WITHOUT SACRIFICING MECHANICAL PERFORMANCE. THE TECHNO-ECONOMIC ANALYSIS (TEA) AND LIFE CYCLE ANALYSIS (LCA) ARE REQUIRED AS PART OF THE FINAL DELIVERABLES AND WILL ANALYZE THE SCIENTIFIC FINDINGS AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY BRINGS VAST ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS BY REDUCING AND ELIMINATING MULTIPLE WASTE MATERIAL STREAMS FROM SEVERAL INDUSTRY SECTORS.

FILER CITY BICRS NET-NEGATIVE STUDY: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COMPLETE INITIAL DESIGN AND DEVELOP COSTING TO RETROFIT THE FILER PLANT WITH THE ABILITY TO FIRE 100% SUSTAINABLY SOURCED BIOMASS AND IMPLEMENT POST-COMBUSTION CO2 CAPTURE TECHNOLOGY. THE FILER PLANT IS A 70 MW GROSS OUTPUT RATED FACILITY WITH TWIN STOKER BOILERS, EACH WITH THE ABILITY TO BURN COAL, WASTE WOOD, CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS, NATURAL GAS, AND TIRED DERIVED FUEL. IT IS THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT TO ELIMINATE THE DEPENDENCE ON COAL AND INCREASE THE FACILITY’S BIOMASS HEAT INPUT TO 100%. IN ADDITION, ADDING POST-COMBUSTION CAPTURE TECHNOLOGY WILL BE INCLUDED TO CAPTURE APPROXIMATELY 670,000 METRIC TONS OF CARBON DIOXIDE FOR PERMANENT SEQUESTRATION IN NORTHERN MICHIGAN. THE PROJECT WILL MEET THE OBJECTIVE OF CAPTURING AND SEQUESTERING AT LEAST 500,000 NET TONS OF CARBON DIOXIDE PER YEAR, BASED ON CRADLE-TO-GATE LIFECYCLE EMISSIONS.

3D PRINTED ENGINEERED STRUCTURES FOR HIGH PERFORMANCE DIRECT AIR CAPTURE SYSTEM. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP NOVEL 3D PRINTED SORBENT STRUCTURES THAT CAN CAPTURE CO2 FROM AIR VIA A RAPID THERMAL SWING ADSORPTION (RTSA) PROCESS.

RESOURCE ASSESSMENT FOR CARBON DIOXIDE STORAGE VIA ACCELERATED CARBONATION REACTION WITH RECYCLED CONCRETE AGGREGATES (RCA)
THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS DEVELOP A PERMANENT CO2 STORAGE VIA THE ACCELERATED CARBONATION PROCESS OF ACCELERATED CARBONATION REACTION WITH RECYCLED CONCRETE AGGREGATES (RCA) USING CO2 OR, ACCELERATED CO2 TREATMENT OF RCA.

ELECTROCHEMICAL-ENABLED CARBON DIOXIDE MINERALIZATION (E-CO2M) OF NATURAL
BRINES AND WASTES TO ENABLE CARBON-NEGATIVE VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS

DEVELOPMENT OF AN ADVANCED CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2) MINERALIZATION TECHNOLOGY FOR COPRODUCTION OF VALUE-ADDED CARBONATE AND FERTILIZER PRODUCTS. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AND VALIDATE AN ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY FOR THE MINERALIZATION OF CO2 FROM INDUSTRIAL SOURCES USING FLUE GAS DESULFURIZATION (FGD) BYPRODUCTS FOR COPRODUCTION OF PRECIPITATED CALCIUM CARBONATE (PCC) AND SULFATE FERTILIZER PRODUCTS.

NEGATIVE-EMISSIONS ENABLED DIRECT AIR CAPTURE WITH COUPLED ELECTRO-PRODUCTION OF HYDROGEN AT A 5 KG-PER-HOUR SCALE

THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN INTENSIFIED AND COST-EFFECTIVE NET NEGATIVE EMISSIONS PROCESS FOR THE DIRECT AIR CAPTURE (DAC) OF CARBON DIOXIDE AT A 5 KG-PER-HOUR SCALE.

BENCH-SCALE DEVELOPMENT OF IONIC LIQUID CATALYZED HIGH-CAPACITY STRUCTURED SORBENTS. THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A HIGH-CAPACITY 
STRUCTURED SORBENT MATERIAL SYSTEM TO MAKE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS TOWARDS REACHING THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY (DOE) CARBON NEGATIVE SHOT TARGET OF LESS THAN $100/NET TONNE CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2) REMOVED.
DISTRIBUTED MAFIC ROCK RESOURCES FOR CO2 MINERALIZATION IN ARIZONA

PROGRAMMATIC COLLABORATION WITH STATE LEGISLATURES TO FOR SUBSURFACE MAFIC AND ULTRAMAFIC ROCK MAPPING AND ANALYSIS FOR CARBON MINERALIZATION IN THE UNITED STATES (SUBMAP-CO2)

THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT AUSTIN IN COLLABORATION WITH COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY WILL CONDUCT A RESOURCE ASSESSMENT OF MAFIC AND ULTRAMAFIC BODIES IN THE SUBSURFACE OF THE USA TO IDENTIFY PERMANENT CO2 STORAGE OPPORTUNITIES. THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THIS WORK IS TO CHARACTERIZE AND DOCUMENT THE VOLUMETRIC EXTENT, MINERALOGY, CRITICAL MINERAL CONTENT, PETROPHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS (GRAIN SIZE, GRAIN DENSITY, POROSITY, PERMEABILITY, AND CARBONATION POTENTIAL AND REACTION RATES OF MAFIC AND ULTRAMAFIC ROCKS IN THE SUBSURFACE OF THE USA WHERE LARGE AMOUNTS OF CO2 CAN BE STORED AS CARBONATE MINERALS VIA CARBONATION REACTIONS). RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL SERVE TO INFORM FUTURE ASSESSMENTS OF RESOURCE UTILITY AND IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR EFFECTIVE, LONG-TERM, SAFE, ECONOMICAL, AND SCALABLE, MINERALIZATION-BASED CO2 STORAGE.
PROJECT TITLE: NET-ZERO LIME KILN AND CARBON REMOVAL FACILITY

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A THOROUGH RESOURCE ASSESSMENT OF NATURAL MATERIALS, AS WELL AS INDUSTRIAL AND MINE WASTES TO BE USED IN BOTH IN-SITU AND EX-SITU CO2 MINERALIZATION PROCESSES IN THE US MID-ATLANTIC REGION. THE FOCUS HERE IS TO ASSESS THE REACTIVITY OF MAFIC AND ULTRAMAFIC FORMATIONS AND CRUSHED MINE AND INDUSTRIAL WASTES WITH CO2, AND THEIR SUITABILITY AS A HOST FOR CO2 MINERALIZATION IN TERMS OF THEIR POST-MINERALIZATION PHYSICAL PROPERTIES SUCH AS POROSITY, PERMEABILITY, AND MECHANICAL ROCK PROPERTIES.

CONVERTING CO2 AND ALKALINE SOLID WASTES TO CARBON-NEGATIVE CEMENT FOR PRECAST CONCRETE UNITS
WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY (ST. LOUIS, MISSOURI) WILL DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE PROCESS FOR PRODUCING A CARBON-NEGATIVE ALTERNATIVE CEMENT FROM CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2) AND SOLID WASTES FOR THE PRODUCTION OF PRECAST CONCRETE UNITS. THE PROJECT WILL DELIVER A LABORATORY-SCALE, PROTOTYPE SYSTEM CAPABLE OF CONVERTING 10 KG CO2 PER DAY FOR CEMENT PRODUCTION.

SUBSURFACE CARBON MINERALIZATION RESOURCES IN HAWAIIAN BASALT

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO PERFORM ASSESSMENT OF NATURAL MATERIALS THAT COULD BE USED IN A MINERALIZATION PROCESS TO STORE LARGE AMOUNTS OF CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2) TO HELP MEET CARBON CAPTURE UTILIZATION AND STORAGE (CCUS) NEEDS.  THIS WILL BE DONE THROUGH ASSESSMENT OF THE CO2 INJECTION AND MINERALIZATION POTENTIAL OF HAWAII ISLAND’S NORTHEAST SUBSURFACE BASALT FORMATIONS.  A WELL THAT WAS DRILLED FOR THE HAWAII SCIENTIFIC DRILLING PROJECT (HSDP) WILL BE UTILIZED TO INVESTIGATE WHETHER BASALT FORMATIONS CAN ACCEPT LARGE AMOUNTS OF CO2 NEEDED FOR MINERALIZATION AT REASONABLE DEPTHS AND MINERALIZATION RATES.  EVALUATION OF THIS BASALT FORMATION FOR MINERALIZATION WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH FIELD WELL TESTING, LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS, AND REACTION MODELING TO POPULATE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATABASES.  SUB-RECIPIENT LAWRENCE BERKELEY NATIONAL LABORATORY WILL SUPPORT ALL PROJECT TASKS.  SUB-RECIPIENT RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY FOR THE EARTH (RITE) WILL PERFORM HYDROTHERMAL EXPERIMENTS ON SAMPLES FROM THE FIELD SITE WELL.  THIS STUDY AND CORRESPONDING DATA ARE EXPECTED TO INFORM FUTURE ASSESSMENTS OF RESOURCE UTILITY AND VALUE FOR MINERALIZATION-BASED CO2 STORAGE.

RESOURCE ASSESSMENT OF INDUSTRIAL WASTES FOR CO2 MINERALIZATION. 

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY WHAT INDUSTRIAL RESIDUE(S) PRESENT THE BEST OPPORTUNITY FOR EFFECTIVE, SAFE, ECONOMIC, AND LONG-TERM CO2 SEQUESTRATION VIA CO2 MINERALIZATION (CO2M) TECHNOLOGIES.

INTEGRATED BENCH-SCALE TESTING OF A STRUCTURED SORBENT FOR DIRECT AIR CAPTURE

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS INTEGRATED BENCH-SCALE PROTOTYPE DEMONSTRATION IS TO ADVANCE A NOVEL SORBENT MATERIAL SYSTEM COMPRISING A HIGHLY DISPERSED SORBENT WITH INTEGRATED ELECTRICAL HEATING FOR REGENERATION ON A LOW-PRESSURE DROP SUBSTRATE FOR DIRECT AIR CAPTURE (DAC) TO JUSTIFY ITS FUTURE SCALE-UP IN A SUBSEQUENT PROGRAM.

AN INTEGRATED AND CONTINUOUS BENCH-SCALE PASSIVE DIRECT AIR CAPTURE DEMONSTRATION. 

THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO DESIGN, FABRICATE, AND CONTINUOUSLY TEST A WIND-DRIVEN BENCH-SCALE DIRECT AIR CAPTURE INTEGRATED PROCESS AND MEASURE KEY PERFORMANCE METRICS.

OVERCOMING TECHNICAL AND COMMUNITY BARRIERS TO ADOPTING GASIFICATION TECHNOLOGIES. 

THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON HUMANITIES-DRIVEN STEM AND IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE UTEP AEROSPACE CENTER AND UTEP COMMUNICATIONS DEPARTMENT. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) PERFORM A SYSTEM CONFIGURATION ANALYSIS OF A 300 KWTH PRESSURIZED MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE (MSW)-BIOMASS CO-GASIFIER, (2) DESIGN, FABRICATE, AND TEST THE PRESSURIZED MSW-BIOMASS CO-GASIFIER; AND (3) DEVELOP PERSUASIVE MESSAGING AND A COMMUNICATION STRATEGY TO EDUCATE POLICYMAKERS AND THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE BENEFITS OF ADOPTING CO-GASIFICATION TECHNOLOGIES.

MITCHELL CEMENT PLANT CARBON CAPTURE FRONT-END ENGINEERING DESIGN (FEED)
THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO COMPLETE A FRONT-END ENGINEERING AND DESIGN (FEED) STUDY AND COST ESTIMATE FOR A COMMERCIAL SCALE CARBON DIOXIDE CAPTURE FACILITY RETROFITTED ONTO THE NEWLY MODERNIZED HEIDELBERG MATERIALS US, INC. MITCHELL, INDIANA CEMENT PLANT.

INDUSTRIAL CARBON CAPTURE FROM AN EXISTING HOT BRIQUETTED IRON MANUFACTURING FACILITY USING THE CRYOCAP FG TECHNOLOGY

LARGE-SCALE DENSITY FUNCTIONAL TIGHT BINDING (DFTB) CALCULATIONS TO PROBE STRUCTURAL EFFECTS AND BRIDGE MULTIPLE LENGTH SCALES IN HYDROGEN-METAL SYSTEM

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COMBINE BOTH DENSITY FUNCTIONAL THEORY (DFT) AND LARGE-SCALE DENSITY FUNCTIONAL TIGHT BINDING (DFTB) APPROACHES TO PROBE FAILURE MECHANISMS, PREDICT THERMODYNAMICS/KINETICS, AND BRIDGE MULTIPLE LENGTH SCALES TO EXPLORE THESE EFFECTS IN HYDROGEN-METAL SYSTEMS. THIS PROJECT EXPLORES (1) THE INTERPLAY BETWEEN KINETICS AND HYDROGEN EFFECTS AT CRYOGENIC CONDITIONS, (2) MECHANISMS OF HYDROGEN-INDUCED STRUCTURAL DAMAGE ACCUMULATION, AND (3) ELUCIDATING FUNDAMENTAL THERMODYNAMIC AND KINETIC BEHAVIOR OF THESE INTERACTIONS. COLLECTIVELY, THESE OBJECTIVES WILL EMPLOY A HIGH DEGREE OF COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION BETWEEN THEM TO REALIZE A FINAL, RIGOROUSLY SOUND, AND VALIDATED COMPUTATIONAL CAPABILITY UPON COMPLETION THAT THE H-MAT TEAM CAN USE TO AUGMENT (AND BRIDGE) THEIR EXISTING QUANTUM AND CLASSICAL MOLECULAR DYNAMICS CAPABILITIES.

SINGLE-WALLED CARBON NANOTUBES WITH CONFINED CHALCOGENS AS THE CATALYSTS AND ELECTRODES FOR OXYGEN REDUCTION REACTION IN FUEL CELLS

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SYNTHESIZE AND CHARACTERIZE THE PROPOSED S@SWNTS AND SE@SWNTS ORR CATALYSTS, UNDERSTAND THEIR FUNDAMENTAL ELECTRONIC STRUCTURES AND THE RELATIONSHIP TO THEIR CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND EVALUATE THE ORR ACTIVITY AND DURABILITY IN MEAS FOR PEMFCS. THE OBJECTIVES FOCUS IN THE FOLLOWING RESEARCH AREAS: (1) SYNTHESIS OF THE PROPOSED S@SWNTS AND SE@SWNT MATERIALS CONSTRUCTED WITH SWNTS OF ENRICHED INDIVIDUAL CHIRALITIES IN THE RANGE OF DIAMETERS 0.8 TO 1.1 NM; (2) FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING OF THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ELECTRONIC STRUCTURE AND CATALYTIC ACTIVITY USING SPECTROSCOPIC, MICROSCOPIC, AND THEORETICAL STUDIES; (3) INVESTIGATING THE CATALYTIC PROPERTIES OF S@SWNTS AND SE@SWNTS VIA ELECTROCHEMICAL ANALYSIS COMBINED WITH SPECTROSCOPIC CHARACTERIZATION; AND (4) FABRICATING INTEGRATED ELECTRODES AND EVALUATING THEIR CATALYTIC ACTIVITY AND DURABILITY FOR ORR IN PEMFCS.

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP NOVEL, LOW COST, PGM-FREE, MOF-BASED HETEROSTRUCTURE CATALYSTS CONTAINING FULLERENE AND MXENE THAT DEMONSTRATE OUTSTANDING ORR-OER ACTIVITY AND STABILITY IN ALKALINE REVERSIBLE FUEL CELLS (SHOWING PROGRESS TOWARDS DOE’S ULTIMATE GOAL OF 65% ROUNDTRIP EFFICIENCY AND =0.125%/1000 HR ACTIVITY LOSS FOR LOW-TEMPERATURE REVERSIBLE FUEL CELLS). TO ACHIEVE THIS, WE WILL LEVERAGE OUR UNIQUE BTA AND BTC-BASED MOF PLATFORM AND THE TEAM’S EXPERTISE IN CREATING NOVEL INTERDIMENSIONAL HETEROSTRUCTURES. FURTHER, THROUGH A SYMBIOTIC THEORETICAL EXPLORATION, WE WILL ESTABLISH A STRUCTURE-ACTIVITY-STABILITY RELATIONSHIP THAT WILL AID THE FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF MOF-BASED HETEROSTRUCTURE CATALYSTS FOR SUSTAINABLE ENERGY APPLICATIONS. THE SPECIFIC PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE:
OBJECTIVE 1: CREATE ENGINEERED MOFS AND HETEROSTRUCTURES
OBJECTIVE 2: DEVELOP STRUCTURE-ACTIVITY CORRELATION AND CONDUCT DEVICE TESTING
OBJECTIVE 3: THEORETICAL PROBING OF CATALYSTS TO UNRAVEL THE FUNDAMENTALS

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP NOVEL HYDROGEN STORAGE MATERIALS THAT EXCEED THE CAPABILITIES OF CURRENT STORAGE MATERIALS NEAR ROOM TEMPERATURES (233 – 333 K) AND LOW PRESSURE (UP TO 100 BAR) AND DISCOVER STRATEGIES TO MEET THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY (DOE) TARGETS FOR ON-BOARD VEHICULAR HYDROGEN STORAGE. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL DESIGN AND SYNTHESIZE HIGHLY POROUS METAL-ORGANIC FRAMEWORKS (MOFS) WITH OPTIMAL STRUCTURAL FEATURES (E.G., SURFACE AREAS, PORE SIZE/VOLUME/SHAPE, CRYSTAL/PACKING DENSITY) FOR HYDROGEN STORAGE. THE HYDROGEN STORAGE CAPACITY OF THE DESIGNED MOFS CAN BE FURTHER IMPROVED BY INTRODUCING ADDITIONAL BINDING SITES, FUNCTIONAL GROUPS AND HYBRIDIZING THEM WITH METAL HYDRIDES. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ENHANCE THE EDUCATION AND TRAINING OF MINORITY STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED/DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES AND DEVELOP A DIVERSE AND HIGHLY SKILLED NEXT-GENERATION WORKFORCE.

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP REVERSIBLE METAL HYDRIDES THAT CAN BE DEHYDROGENATED AND RECHARGED AT RELATIVELY LOW TEMPERATURES AND PRESSURES. THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ARE: (1) TO FABRICATE NANOSCALE MAGNESIUM BORIDE POWDERS WITH VARIOUS B/MG ATOMIC RATIOS USING MECHANICALLY-ACTIVATED SELF-PROPAGATING HIGH-TEMPERATURE SYNTHESIS (MASHS); (2) TO INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTS OF B/MG ATOMIC RATIO AND PARTICLE SIZE ON THE HYDROGENATION AND DEHYDROGENATION PROPERTIES OF THE OBTAINED MAGNESIUM BORIDES.
DEVELOPMENT OF A NOVEL, NEAR REAL TIME APPROACH TO GEOTHERMAL SEISMIC EXPLORATION AND MONITORING VIA AMBIENT SEISMIC NOISE INTERFEROMETRY
